content:
Hi,

I've recently finished my PhD and would like to start contributing to Rust in my spare time...

My background has been in implementing compiler and runtime support for GPGPU acceleration in Java and so my comfort zone would be working with the mid-to-low end of the compiler (MIR/codegen). However, I'm really open to just getting stuck in so can join in where needed? (Any pointers to projects would be great?)

My main blocker to getting started would be learning (or going through) the PR submission process a couple of times, so I might need a little bit of hand holding -- is there any low-hanging fruit or janitorial tasks that I could make a start with to get me going?

Hi @James clarkson! Congrats on finishing your PhD! Have you seen the rustc dev guide? There are several issue labels you may be interested in like A-codegen and A-mir. There is also the E-easy label.

There is a chapter in the rustc-dev-guide about contributing, you’ll find all the information you need about the PR submission process.

The rustc-dev-guide also has a whole part called From MIR to binaries, I think you could skim through it and find an area that could interest you?
Thanks @bjorn3 and @LeSeulArtichaut for the pointers. I will take a look.
After I find an issue to work on am I ok to claim it?
Yes, you are free to claim an issue when nobody else is working on it. You can comment @rustbot claim to make rustbot assign you.
Thanks that was the bit I was missing.
